statement.p: Consider the radioactive decay model for Bismuth-212: \displaystyle{A}={14.5}{\left(\frac{{1}}{{2}}\right)}^{{{t}{/}{60.55}}}
where \displaystyle{t} is in units of minutes.
What is the annual percent increase or decrease?
Use 365 days/year, 8760 hours per year, and 525600 minutes per year.

solution.p: The initial amount is the coefficient in front, because when \displaystyle{t}={0} the second factor is just one. So the initial amount is 14.5.
To obtain the annual percent decrease, we need to convert the units to years. 60.55 minutes is \displaystyle\frac{{60.55}}{{525600}}={0.00011520167427702} years.

Next we need to convert to the form \displaystyle{\left({1}+{p}\right)}^{{t}}. We can do this by expanding \displaystyle{\left(\frac{{1}}{{2}}\right)}^{{\frac{{t}}{{0.00011520167427702}}}}={\left({\left(\frac{{1}}{{2}}\right)}^{{\frac{{1}}{{0.00011520167427702}}}}\right)}^{{t}}={0}^{{t}}. Now we can calculate the percent decrease as \displaystyle{1}-{0}={1}. Converting to percent this is \displaystyle{100}{\left({1}\right)}={100}\%.
